title: What will be the total domestic box office gross for Tenet as of 8 September 2020, according to Box Office Mojo?
possible_answers: More than $80 million but less than $160 million
preds: Tenet's opening weekend numbers make the other buckets impossible.
Less than a day to go and domestic box office currently at ~ $20M according to Box Office Mojo.
Updateing forecast given data coming in for long-weekend showing roughly 20 million in domestic box office gross.

At 20MM right now after being released September 3 in the US and closing tomorrow; will not exceed 80 million by tomorrow.  Note: Even without Covid, Nolan's last several films have grossed less than 80MM domestically in the first five days.

According to “Box Office Mojo” on September 7, 2020, Tenet grossed $20 million during the Labor Day weekend in the US (https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl1442940417/weekend/), whereas Forbes.com reported a figure of $20.2 million (https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2020/09/07/box-office-movies-tenet-chris-nolan-150m-robert-pattinson-john-david-washington-dunkirk-interstellar-inception/#4760309c3885), including whatever it made in Canada in the seven prior days.  Considering that the Labor Day weekend was the film’s inaugural weekend, of its weekend’s performance, and that 65% of U.S. movie theaters were opened (https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-tenet-opens-to-20m-as-u-s-theaters-reopen-nears-150m-globally), with limitation, it cannot be expected that the figure for revenue, for that weekend reported as of September 8th will be above $100 million.
Over the past two days, Tenet has grossed around $20 million, making it completely impossible for it to be in any other category. This update puts Tenet directly in the 1-80 category
Going to be annoyed if my B score is hurt because I forgot to update this even though I was early to the "maybe $1m is not a lock" show.
Tenet's box office up until Sept.6th (labor day weekend) was 20.1m. It is impossible to grow 60m in two days.
New boxmojo estimate has a weekend estimate of $20.2M for Sep 4-7. Should firmly be in the $1-80M bucket now.

"After months of delays Christopher Nolan’s “Tenet” finally landed in U.S. theaters over the weekend, cashing in more than $20 million in ticket sales ... The domestic debut comes one week after “Tenet” opened internationally and marks the highest-grossing opening weekend for a film in the U.S. since the pandemic began ... “Tenet” in pre-covid times would have been expected to tally between $35 million and $55 million during its opening weekend, on par with other Nolan films like “Interstellar” and “Inception.” The $20 million is reflective of a 50% cap on attendance at theaters and that only around 65% of cinemas have reopened to the public. " https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/06/tenet-scores-20-million-in-biggest-domestic-opening-since-pandemic.html

Box Office already hit 20 million, and I think the chance of it reaching 80 is essentially negligible with 2 days left until settlement, of which one is a weekday where box office will likely realize much lower than this weekend, and one is Labor Day, which I believe will have an indeterminate to slightly negative effect on box office.

Tenet has successfully debuted in US cinemas and first box offices are releasing debut numbers. We see that the movie will be >$1M and most predictions suggest an opening week with $20M revenue. This basically makes extremely unlikely for the movie to fall into another bucket than the second one ($1M - $80M). Even though 100/0 would suggest absolute certainty, given that we need to round our estimates, we now submit our forecast change to be 100/0.
Current domestic box office sits at ~20mn. Given the large range between 1mn and 80mn, assigning 100% is justified.

Articles published today say it's grossed 20.2 mm up to date, but it's unclear whether that stat includes last night's numbers which would make a big difference. Either way, it seems less likely will peak 80 by tues.

Making box-office gross available is a norm, but it’s not a requirement. For “Tenet,” Warners decided to buck tradition and withhold information, thereby avoiding much of the rush to judgment. It also allows the studio greater capacity to spin.I see this as a signal that Warners would likely prefer that comparisons not be made at all. -> so i updated the 1-80 million from 99 to 100%. I really don't see any chance that it can be less than a million, as mentioned by @ConnorTB  it is kind of equivalent to 0 theater opened in the U.S.
Tenet has debuted in US theaters successfully, all I need to see to change to 100% on the second bucket. Hopefully the movie is good!
it's hard to imagine anything over 80 million in the current economic environment, especially looking at prior releases in recent months.
1-80M looking increasingly likely as China is now projecting $25-30M in box office for the weekend down from the original $50M. BoxOffice is currently projecting $35M as well.

Domestic box office sales usually account for 40% of a movie's box office gross. Given that the international box office gross for Tenet is $53.6 mil, under normal circumstances we would expect the film to gross $35.7 mil domestically. Christopher Nolan's last three films all grossed over $50 mil (with the highest grossing $62.8 mil) on their opening weekend showing on approximately 3700 screens. Given that tenet will show on only 2000 screens and theaters are only allowing about 50% capacity, we could expect about 1/4 of the domestic gross of his previous movies, or about $13 million. However, early screenings could make up for some of the lost revenue. Likely, Tenet with gross somewhere between $13 mil and $35.7 mil.

taking into account these, making a slight adjustment down from my most recent prediction https://screenrant.com/tenet-movie-box-office-opening-weekend-predictions/
https://rogersmovienation.com/2020/09/04/will-tenet-reopen-the-box-office-just-in-time-for-labor-day/

Due to strong(ish) openings overseas, I will recalibrate my projection.
https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2020/08/30/movies-box-office-tenet-chris-nolan-john-david-washington-robert-pattinson-53m/#4edb002730d7

BoxOfficeMojo so far shows no domestic grosses, which makes the site appear slow.
So far UK has raked the highest gross: 7,123,704 USD (as of 04 September 2020, probably; since 28 August 2020), followed by
France: 6,800,000 USD and
South Korea: 5,100,000 USD (both since 26 August 2020)
combined ~19mn USD. Population-wise these three countries combined are about 60% of the US total. If you could compare them by lifestyle, price level/purchase power and leisure behavior, then this indicates that Tenet might gross 30 to 35mn USD domestically for about the same time span of about 6 days. Further reading:
"Estimates place Tenet's opening weekend theater count between 2,750 and 3,000 locations." https://www.cbr.com/tenets-theatrical-run-longer-than-modern-movies/ "AMC Theatres plan to reopen 70 percent of its locations for the Labor Day weekend release of Tenet in the U.S., following its Safe & Clean protocols. [...] In California, seven AMC theaters in San Diego County can open at 25 percent capacity, per Phase 2 limits set by the state. San Francisco County is also in Phase 2, but there are currently no reopening plans set. New Jersey allowed theaters to reopen this week at 25 percent capacity as well."
https://www.cbr.com/tenet-amc-reopen-70-percent-theaters-christopher-nolan-blockbuster/
Hopefully, the BOM site will catch up with reality before 08 September 2020 and shows at least some of the gross, otherwise the GJ jury might be tempted to resolve this question on the first bin for "no data available"...

Question and current situation: Tenet movie has $53,600,000 boxoffice gross for worlwide data as the film is not released yet in the US (release date Sep 3, 2020). On Mojo [1], "Domestic" refers to gross box-office revenue from North America (U.S., Canada, and Puerto Rico), "International" covers the rest of the world. The objective of the questions is to estimate the total domestic box office gross for Tenet as of 8 September 2020, according to Box Office Mojo? So 5 days domestic box office.
My strategy is
1/ to have first an outside view looking at historical data for similar movies (Nolan previous movies for instance) to get the average domestic gross in the first 5 days after release. Previous Nolan movie in US
Inception with release date July 15, 2010 (EMEA, APAC) has a domestic gross for the 5 first days (given it was out on Friday 16th-> we effect) of + 83 million [2]
Interstellar released on November 5, 2014 (EMEA, Domestic) $49,661,813 [3]
2/ Regress from Europe to get insight on how this specific movie is performing. Chris Nolan's Tenet is off to a very solid start, topping all 41 overseas territories in which it opens, provided it indeed gets the post-opening legs that Warner Bros. is banking upon for global box office success. In normal times, a $53 million overseas launch (including $5 million in IMAX) for a film as big as Chris Nolan’s Tenet would be, at the very least, somewhat disappointing.
3/ consider the labor day factor here
At this outside view stage I will have 40% > 80 million and 60% < 80 million. / Then, I adapt my first forecast with covid situation speicificity, given
A) the number of theaters opened in domestic (US, canada, domestic) -> AMC Entertainment announced that it would reopen roughly 140 additional theaters by Sept. 4, bringing a total of 70 percent of its movie theaters in the United States back into operation. [5]
B) the appetite of people to go to theater -> I think less than 30% capacity
Balancing those forces I will go for 98% Between $1 million and $80 million, inclusive and 2% / Then, I adapt my first forecast with covid situation speicificity, given
A) the number of theaters opened in domestic (US, canada, domestic) -> AMC Entertainment announced that it would reopen roughly 140 additional theaters by Sept. 4, bringing a total of 70 percent of its movie theaters in the United States back into operation. [5]
B) the appetite of people to go to theater -> I think less than 30% capacity
Balancing those forces I will go for 98% Between $1 million and $80 million, inclusive and 2% / Then, I adapt my first forecast with covid situation speicificity, given
A) the number of theaters opened in domestic (US, canada, domestic) -> AMC Entertainment announced that it would reopen roughly 140 additional theaters by Sept. 4, bringing a total of 70 percent of its movie theaters in the United States back into operation. [5]
B) the appetite of people to go to theater -> I think less than 30% capacity
Balancing those forces I will go for 98% Between $1 million and $80 million, inclusive and 2% for More than $80 million but less than $160 million [1] https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl1442940417/
[2] https://www.boxofficemojo.com/daily/2010/?view=year
[3] https://www.boxofficemojo.com/date/2014-11-09/?ref_=bo_di_table_53
[4] https://www.boxofficemojo.com/date/2008-07-22/?ref_=bo_di_table_163
[5] https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/09/01/business/stock-market-today-coronavirus
They are anticipating $20 million the first weekend.  https://deadline.com/2020/09/tenet-international-box-office-china-christopher-nolan-1234571094/

We derive a base rate using the 5 day box office opening across multiple different countries adjusted for population and wealth from https://www.boxofficemojo.com/title/tt6723592/. We then average the rates across each derived rate from each country (example: If canada is x the size of US, then we would take the box office results from canada and divide by x, then multiply by an adjustment factor via the average median income). I did this for the top countries to arrive at a base rate within the range of roughly 30-50 MM, which puts me solidly within my described range.

Dunkirk and Inception grossed less in better times. Box office openings in the past few weeks have all been in this range. Christopher Nolan should be enough of a draw to get over 1mm but it seems extremely unlikely to get more than 80mm.
The movie release seems to have gone ahead, updating prediction

According to Box Mojo data, Christopher Nolan's movies' box office break down has an average of 30% domestic, 70% international. Tenet has been debut for the international audience for about one week and earned $55m international box office in total (data as of 9/3/2020). Without considering the coronavirus situation, since we are five days until the 9/8 deadline, the expected domestic box office is 55 * 5 /7 = $40m. On Sep 3rd, my expected movie theater capacity is at most 50% because of the hard coronavirus in-door activity limit. Besides, the biggest movie theater chains in the U.S. were acting in about 30% capacity on August 20th, which serves as a bottom line (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/20/coronavirus-amc-regal-and-cinemark-prepare-to-reopen-in-the-us-after-five-month-shutdown.html). Thus, the expected domestic box office is then $40*30% to $40*50%, which gives me 12m to 20m. I left a 1% margin in the bins below and above 1-80m margin for special scenarios, such as a sudden shut-down of all movie theaters/Tenet was much more welcomed by the American audience than the international ones.

https://www.boxofficemojo.com/showdown/sd977073668/ other Christopher Nolan movies have grossed around $50 million on the opening weekend, whereas this challenge extends two more days. Given COIVD, it is more plausible that the movie would perform less well than comparable ones, however. I also noted that movie sales on Mondays and Tuesdays are likely to be much lower than weekends, meaning the additional two days may not add much
Launch date was today and no mention of any delay. Given past data, box office should certainly be above $1M. Will reevaluate >$80M bucket after early data comes out.

Comparable Nolan movies have all grossed less than 160 million during the first weekend. Furthermore, I found that international box office tends to account for ~1/2 - 2/3 of total revenue in high grossing movies. After grossing 50 million internationally, I do not expect Tenet to break that mark domestically given US' covid-19 situation which is relatively worse than most countries, small population relative to the rest of the world (1.5 billion total English speakers if you use that as a rough proxy of potentially interested moviegoers), and lack of theaters open, as Zach cited. A counterpoint to this is that the reviews for the movie are quite good (though not stellar by Nolan's standards) so I do not count out the minute chance that Americans make it out to see the movie.  https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl1442940417/

Given that Tenet released in US theaters today (9/3), there is little reason to believe that it will gross less than $1 million, considering that the top movies for the last three weeks have all grossed greater than that. As for the upper bound, we can look at Christopher Nolan's previous three original movies. Inception, Inception, Interstellar, and Dunkirk have had $82.6m, $61.8m, and $64.3m as their opening 5-day domestic grosses (data from Box Office Mojo). However, obviously COVID has drastically reduced sales expectations, with only 62% of theaters open and all with social distancing in place. Additionally, the fact that more than half of Americans are extremely unlikely to go to a movie theater a month after they reopen, makes it seem extremely unlikely that Tenet will exceed $80 million (https://fortune.com/2020/09/03/tenet-us-movie-theaters-box-office-coronavirus-pandemic-release/). This lines up with analysts' forecast of about $25-35 million in opening week sales (https://www.boxofficepro.com/long-range-box-office-forecast-christopher-nolans-tenet/). If opening weekend sales are drastically higher than expected, I could adjust this forecast before the deadline.

According to data sources pointed out by my colleague, @dzhou3 , we expect Tenet to open in roughly 3000 theaters in limited capacity. Further the release date for this movie was today, so we are estimating the amount of money this movie will gross over the next 5 days. It may be also noteworthy that these 5 days will include a public holiday, Labor Day, a popular weekend for movies historically.  As a lower bound, I look at a recently released movie, Bill & Ted Face the Music starring Keanu Reeves. This movie was released on Aug 28th, so there is 6 days worth of cash flow aggregated in the current Box Office Mojo view. As of writing, that movie has grossed 1.3 million. While this movie stars a big name in Keanu Reeves, the budget for the film was roughly 25 million USD, and this movie was only released in roughly 1000 theatres. Further, in regards to box office sales, action genre movies tend to do much better than comedy genre films, which Bill &Ted Face the Music falls under. In contrast, Tenet has all the makings of a box office hit, including a start cast with Robert Pattinson, a renowned director in Christopher Nolan, and a budget of 225 million. For these reasons, I am confident that the lower bound for Tenet’s gross domestic revenue is more than 1 million. To estimate an upper bound, we use an aggressive benchmark –Bad Boys for Life, the third installation in the popular Bad Boys series starring Will Smith and Martin Lawrence. Bad Boys for Life was released in January 2020, well before the covid-19 crisis shuttered cinemas, and performed very well in the box office. This movie, which falls in the action genre, was created with a budget of $90 million and was opened in 3,775 theaters. Similarly to Tenet, this movie’s first five days included a public holiday,  MLK  day. In it’s first five days grossed $79.5 million (https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl1182631425/weekend/?ref_=bo_rl_tab#tabs).  While Tenet has a larger budget than Bad Boys for Life, Tenet is being released in much fewer theatres, and will have limited attendance. For this reason, I believe the 79.5 million benchmark from Bad Boys for Life is a reasonable upper bound.  Finally, I do believe that it is possible that Tenet can perform extremely well in its first few days, perhaps people may be really eager to go back into theaters, although I would not put too much weight behind the probability Tenet will cross $80 million.

The battle with COVID in the US is constantly evolving, and this has a huge potential to impact a movie's gross earnings. Because of this, I did not feel comfortable using data that was more than a month old. On boxofficemojo.com, I observed that the highest grossing recent movies were The New Mutant, Unhinged, and The Spongebob Movie. Since Tenet is a highly-anticipated movie directed by Christopher Nolan, it makes sense to treat the opening 6 days of these movies as a floor for the prediction for Tenet. The domestic numbers were: The New Mutants: $7,954,226
Unhinged: $5,957,685
Spongebob: $1,368,443 All three of these movies opened at over $1,000,000, so that is a highly probable floor for Tenet given that it is a high-profile release. Furthermore, these movies have combined domestic gross revenues of $20,149,123 (not just in the first week). Tenet is certainly a much higher-profile movie than these three (anecdotally, I had heard about Tenet, and not about the others). Therefore while $20,149,123 is the right order of magnitude for an upper bound on Tenet's revenue in its first 6 days, I do think there is a chance that a revenue of $80 million could be surpassed. While people are certainly avoiding theaters due to COVID, they haven't had a high-profile movie like Tenet to attract them to theaters, which could cause a surprise effect in which more people go to the movie than would normally be the case. Furthermore, cases and deaths have been on a slight decline recently. Therefore, while I'm betting strongly on the revenue being between 1 and 80 million, I do want to place some probability on the movie exceeding expectations and surpassing 80 million. But that scenario requires a lot of assumptions and I am only giving it a 2% chance. Intuitively I do think there are greater than 1/100 scenarios in which this happens, but not much higher than that.

Methodology: We used a baseline model to find an initial forecast and then used individual situation dependent issues to adjust our score. Baseline: We first create a comparable movies space that contains all the movies that critics deemed to be similar to this movie. Critics identified 7 movies that are quite close to this movie, such as Insomnia (2002), Primer (2004), Looper (2012). Looking at all these moves from the past we get an average first week domestic box office value of $15.5M with a median value of $15.01M. Adjustments:
Christopher Nolan premium: Christopher Nolan is a very well-known filmmaker in the movie industry, thus his movies might garner more interest. Indeed, if we look at comparable movies created by Christopher Nolan (e.g. Inception (2010), Dunkirk (2017), Prestige (2006)), we see that the average value of such movies is $67.8M with a median value of $63.1M. Furthermore, Christopher Nolan movies consistently have a gross box office revenue of over $20M, thus this should give an indication of a lower cap and reinforces a base value. Labor Day weekend adjustment:
As suggested by @dzhou3 , we also looked at the biggest box office openings that happened on a Labor Day weekend, and we saw that the highest revenue was $30M and is not statistically significantly different from other weekends. Coronavirus adjustment:
Due to Covid-19 pandemic, theaters all over the country have closed from one day to another. Local theaters went bankrupt and the whole movie industry shut down. However, with recent reopenings it is expected that Tenet will be released to open in more than 3,000 theaters. Even though this is not the same size as before, it is not much smaller as before. Furthermore, as @kramlal pointed out, recent releases in this Covid environment have not made movies completely go extinct (Keanu Reeves movie made $1.3M since its release on August 28) and people show interest in trying to regain a somewhat normal life. Upper boundaries:
We also look at possible upper boundaries for this movie to understand how our distribution should be skewed. We see that there are 3 movies in recent history with an opening week of >$240M and 17 movies >$160M. However, these moves are almost all part of a huge movie franchise (e.g. Marvel Universe, Star Wars), thus these movies might not be good comparables at all and indicate that this specific movie should not be compared to these. It also shows that if the movie is not in a huge franchise, it is not likely that it will be able to get that much interest from the public. Conclusion: Adding together all these factors, we see that the vast majority of our probable distribution lies between $1M and $80M given that there is no precedence for a Christopher Nolan movie to be below $1M and Covid should not make it improbable for a movie to achieve it, but on the upper side, going above $160M is also virtually impossible. Also, given how few movies make it to over $80M and this movie's script is not a typical blockbuster, we put the distribution as shown above.

updating after convo with @RSparkes. Adjusting pre-covid gross estimate to 50 - 150 mm range. Using .167 and .536 capacity for movie seats I have lower and upper bound of 8.4 - 80.4. Adjusting for pent up covid demand adjusts to 8.4 - 100.4. Using uniform dist, gives 78% chance of 1 - 80 mm range. 22% for >80
International ~ 55m, and many countries are out of lockdowns with cinema open. Therefore, compared to movies with similar budgets, US should be >1mm, < 88m.

Largest ever box office of a labor day release was 30m. Tenet grossed ~50m in EU + EMEA during its first week, based on data from watch mojo the US box office seems to be roughly equal to EU + EMEA for big ticket releases such as this, suggeesting Tenet will likely gross in this range. I also check weekly box office figures on: https://www.the-numbers.com/box-office-chart/weekly/2020/08/14 since the coronavirus outbreak in March, the total weekly gross has not exceeded 10m across all movies. While cinemas are reopening in the US, an 8x the previous weeks total gross would be quite astonishing for Tenet.

Several factors / benchmarks to consider here when establishing / adjusting a prior, where we're primarily focused on calculating the tail risk of gross falling outside the $1mm-$80mm bin: 1. Tenet's $53mm international open:
Tenet's strong interest in Asia (not China) and European markets, despite preventative measures / closed theaters / limited seating in various countries (ex. South Korea) points to a domestic open of $30 mm (Forbes). 2. COVID lockdown:
Limited seating capacity due to COVID and projected figure of at least 2,400 domestic theaters (particularly with NYC, LA closed) suggests trimming our base estimate. As a worst case scenario, "The New Mutants,” in the “X-Men” franchise, opened to $7 million in 2,412 locations this weekend with a global debut of $9.9 million. "New Mutants" had a 32% “rotten” rating and also less international interest compared to Tenet- yet still finished at 7x the lower bound, which provides a large margin of safety on the lower bound for our estimate. 3. Other Christopher Nolan film openings:
"... average debut weekend of Nolan’s last three original films (Inception, Interstellar, and Dunkirk) is $53.6 million. At $62.8 million, the former of that trio is the highest — and probably the most relevant comparison to Tenet given the global scale and action/espionage genre commonalities." (Boxofficechicago) Tenet has a rating of 78% fresh on Rotten Tomatoes and a Metacritic score of 68, which puts it below the usual Nolan standards; this provides a strong upper bound of <$70mm in the opening weekend. 5. Labor day weekend:
Current record for a Fri-Mon Labor Day opening is $30.5 million in 2007; the extra free day does not warrant a sufficiently high multiplier to assign a probability to bin 3. To summarize: for Tenet to gross more than $80mm in its opening, it would have to exceed Nolan's previous three films during a national lockdown with only a fraction of theaters open, including none in NYC / LA. Risks to the upside are minimal even with strong international showing / positive critical reception / Labor Day weekend. Risks to the downside: "New Mutants" performance provides strong margin of safety, even with COVID measures. Only potential risk would be lack of compliance with safety protocols (Vanity Fair), which has a chance of forcing a further delay; given short timeframe of prediction and imminent release I find this incredibly unlikely. Links:
https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2020/08/tenet-box-office-christopher-nolan
https://www.boxofficepro.com/long-range-box-office-forecast-christopher-nolans-tenet/
https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2020/08/30/movies-box-office-tenet-chris-nolan-john-david-washington-robert-pattinson-53m/#4ea9c8e030d7
https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/movies/story/2020-08-30/box-office-new-mutants-tenet-copperfield

I believe that much of the demand for Christopher Nolan's movies (especially when first released) is driven by people knowing they're directed by Nolan. So, looking at initial box office revenue for prior Christopher Nolan's movies is a good starting point for determining demand for Tenet.  Since Tenet releases domestically on September 3rd (tomorrow) and the prediction settles on September 8th, we're predicting the first 5 days of its box office revenue. Inception earned $82.7M gross in its first 5 days, Dunkirk earned $64.3M, and Interstellar earned $50M. The Dark Knight series is not a fair comparison due to the pre-existing hype surrounding the Batman franchise and subsequent movies in a series generally boosts demand. Given COVID, there are partial closures and decreased demand for theatres, so I am almost certain (> 99.5%) that Tenet will be earning less than Inception, Dunkirk, and Interstellar.  On the flip side, given that Tenet has already released internationally on August 26th and made $53M in international markets over 7 days, there is almost no chance that Tenet will postpone their domestic release date or that it won't be able to make at least $1M in 5 days (given that domestic market gross revenue is usually more than half of international market gross revenue).

First forecast is done without doing any "specific" or "rigorous" data analysis techniques but rather from taking a holistic view at the question and the data we have so far.  Tenet is currently scheduled for release on 9/3, and barring any major reversal/collapse it will certainly pass at least the $1M mark as it's a major movie release. International box office has been quite strong so far and has grossed $53.6M since its opening day on 8/26 worldwide. I found the global box office revenue in 2019 was $42.5B compared with $11.4B for domestic box office (source: billboard.com), although stats for opening weekend may perform differently.  Another article from washingtonpost suggested that analysts are optimistically forecasting $40M domestic box office for opening weekend with strong international box office as a key indicator. Part of the reason they were optimistic about sales was due to the fact that there isn't much competition with other releases at the moment. Either way, the $80M threshold for the 3rd bin seems quite hard to beat, thus we can confidently forecast between $1M and $80M as of now.  Will be sure to update after I'm able to take a closer look at historical releases.

We observed two Christopher Nolan movies, Dunkirk and Inception, noting that Inception was more successful. Given that currently 1 week after international release, the movie has grossed ~$57 million, we strongly believe that box office revenues will be in the $1 million to $80 million bucket. Dunkirk grossed $64 million in the first 5 days, while Inception grossed $82 million. Both of these movies released in pre-Covid America and were fairly recent. Thus $80 million seems like a very strong upper bound for Tenet's box office earnings. Tenet is opening in 80% of American theaters to begin with, and many of these will have social distancing restrictions, which will limit seating and demand.

As @ashalom mentioned, the movie will have 5 days to accrue revenue at the box office. Considering movie theaters are open around the country and past opening box office revenues, it is expected that the movie will generate at least $1m. The greatest risk is that the movie will be further delayed. However, considering the proximity to September 8th, this is highly unlikely.
Currently around 53.6 million.  Unlikely to rise above 80 in the next 6 days, although more theaters are opening this weekend around the country.
Given opening weekend numbers in overseas territories, historical opening weekends, and current covid restrictions in the U.S. I have more probability in the <1mm bucket than in the >80mm bucket.

The movie releases on Sept 3, giving it only 5 days to accrue revenue.
Christopher Nolan's last movie (Dunkirk, 2017) had domestic opening-week gross of $74.7mm, while Interstellar (2014) had domestic opening week gross of $66mm. These net out to approximately $20k and $19k per theater respectively.
AMC announced it is opening about 70% of movie theaters for release of Tenet. Some of these movie theaters (NJ, California) must open at 25% capacity, while theaters in populous states such as NY will not even open.
If we make optimistic assumptions: average $20k per theater (same as Dunkirk, with what will likely be much less capacity), approximately 70% of theaters open (of which we assume 75% are operating at same capacities as in 2017), this gives us a revenue projection of $42mm. 
It is hard to envision the movie being such a flop as to have less than $1mm revenue; instead, this should represent probability of movie being delayed even further. This close to release (tomorrow!), this is extremely unlikely.

In order to have a base case of how movies are performing right now, I looked at the top 5 highest grossing domestic films in August 2020. As a side note, Tenet is expected to debut on September 3rd in about 3,000 theaters domestically (source: https://www.indiewire.com/2020/07/tenet-opens-september-3-theaters-future-1234576434/ ). Of the top 5, only Unhinged and The New Mutants (TNM) are apt comparisons to Tenet since they had larger debuts of several thousand theaters. Furthermore, Unhinged is a rather noisy estimate of how much theaters are making on films nowadays since it had an initial limited debut followed by a wider debut of around 2,000 theaters. Thus, we will focus on using TNM as the base case. Using the data from the first 4 days domestic revenue of TNM  (per theater avg.) and the fact that Tenet will debut in approx. 3,000 theaters domestically, I have an estimated 4 day domestic revenue of Tenet of about $9.3m. Since this will be a 5 day estimate, Tenet is arguably a much more popular film that TNM and the fact that the time range will include Labor Day, we can safely assume that Tenet will be more than $1m.  Now let us arrive at an EV and upper bound. To get an upper bound, I consider the highest grossing Labor Day weekend release of all time, Halloween (Source: https://www.boxofficemojo.com/chart/release_top_weekend_gross/?by_occasion=us_laborday_weekend&ref_=bo_rl_rr). Halloween released on a Friday whereas Tenet will release on a Thursday so the weekday difference is not huge. Using Halloween's average theater revenue for the first 5 days and the 3,000 theater debut estimate for Tenet, we get an upper bound of $27.7m. For EV, I take a weighted average of the average daily revenue per theater between TNM (1/3 weight) and Halloween (2/3 weight) for the first 4 days (since that's all the data we have for TNM) and arrive at an EV of 20.7m + say 1m for the 5th day = $21.7m. 1/2 and 2/3 are simply assumptions but seems reasonable to take into account COVID vs. popularity of the film. As such, with our lower and upper bounds squarely between $1m and $80m, I assign a high probability to the $1m-$80m bracket with low probabilities on <$1m and $80m-$160m.

As of August 31, Tenent has already earned $53MM and ranks #9 for 2020 in the worldwide box office, prior to the US launch.  Due to minimal competition, Tenent also will likely have a lengthy run.  In 2020, gross is about 70% - 80% of total.  Most recently, The New Mutants, an action horror sci-fi was released in theaters and earned $7MM opening weekend.  With a similar genre, and more excitement around the film due to cast, director, and budget, we can expect Tenent to perform much higher.  In 2017, Christopher Nolan’s Dunkirk earned $188MM gross in the box office.  With Americans hungry for things to do, ready for new movies, and theaters opening up, we can expect Tenent to perform much higher than The New Mutants, though not as high as it would have pre-pandemic as many are still staying home.

Wow, was NOT expecting a pushback of only two weeks [1].  This leads me to reduce <$1M and increase $1M-$80M.  As I've said before, <$1M is basically a proxy for "does not open within subject timeframe".  The fact that they pushed only two weeks translates to me as significantly reducing the likelihood that the movie will not open within subject timeframe. They could punt a second time to after subject timeframe, but I put that probability at about 8% at this point. I therefore reduce <$1M to that amount, allocating the reduction to $1M-$80M and $80M-$160M. All said, I'm overshooting $80M-160M for a bit to fatten up the weighted average there...because I have historically been quite a bit lower than my current POV. The trailer was released without a release date, making it more likely that it is delayed (~35%, my guess). However, August 14 looks like another option if it is delayed [1]. 
Given an August 14th release, I'd expect it to almost certainly gross below $80 million, possibly even under $1 million, though unlikely (~90% > 1 million). If we assume the August 14 date is fifty-fifty given a delay, with the other option being after Sept. 8, then the < 1 million probability becomes 20%. 
In the event of a July 17 release (~65%), then I'd say there's a 100% chance it exceeds $1 million, and there's a possibility that it exceeds $80 million, but I find this unlikely. However, a lot can change in 2-4 months so I'll bump up my estimate of above 80 to about 10% (given July 17 release). Therefore, greater than 80 has roughly 7%. I give 1% to 160-240 only because I think about how poorly I would've predicted today's events three and a half months ago.  [1] https://www.slashfilm.com/tenet-release-date-possibilities/

Relative to the crowd, I think that >80 million is not that unrealistic, despite the most likely outcome being <80 million. Dunkirk made ~ 80 million domestic in about 1 week. Assuming they stick to the Jul 17 release date, that gives Tenet more than 1 month to do what Dunkirk did in one week — seems like theaters filling at 25% capacity is not too out of the question and Tenet won't be competing with anything. We don't have data on how willing people are to go to the theater, so I'm totally in the dark about that component. But I am somewhat optimistic about them sticking to the Jul 17 date. The website and twitter say so, Nolan seems to really want a theatrical release, and even if it gets pushed a month that still gives it time to make some money. I assign a significantly higher probability to the higher gross amounts (>160 million) than the crowd because I just don't know how consumer's willingness to go out and see a movie will change over the next few months. It seems unlikely, but if Tenet receives excellent press, is viewed as the only entertainment available, and theaters do a good job rolling out social distancing measures, it might be plausible that it does big numbers. We're simply bad at knowing how COVID and consumer behavior will progress more than 1 month out, so we should be more uncertain!

Nolan did a 188 M domestic box office with Dunkirk and is a brand by himself. Also, Dunkirk did 167 M in its first 30 days.  But July might be a bit early for a wide release, and given the 7 weeks that the film has from release to Sep 8th - my baseline estimates are as follows. Less than 1 M  (25%) - This is to account for a potential delay in release
1 M to 80 M      (70%) - Seems to be the most possible
80 M to 160 M  (05%) - To account for any overflows Anything above 160 M seems very difficult.

Warner Bros is believed to have spent $200 million on producing the movie before advertising costs are included so it is unlikely to be released in July if very few people are going to the theatre. In case it is released in July, I have used some figures from Nolan's previous movies in order to forecast the total box office gross, but taking into account the fact that they were released under normal circumstances. On opening, Inception took $62 million, Interstellar took $47 million and Dunkirk took $50 million.

Christopher Nolan's "Tenet" is still scheduled as the first major studio release to hit theaters when they reopen, possibly by July. But, a new poll shows 70% of people would rather skip the theater and watch "Tenet," or any other new release, on the couch. 13% said they would rather go to the theater than stream at home and 17% are not sure. For our question of the day, we want to know: Would you rather watch a new movie in theaters or at home?  This was a FB/TV sta poll.(KATV)

Interstellar Domestic Numbers: Opening Weekend: $47.5m and Total: $188m Dunkirk Domestic Numbers: Opening Weekend: $50.5m and Total: $190m Included the Opening Weekend numbers, as it may be delayed, which would lead to less time in the theaters. Feel like there is no chance that Tenet will have a bigger total box office than Dunkirk and Interstellar had under normal circumstances. While it is a Nolan movie and the only movie out, it is still not a Star Wars or Marvel movie.  Thus, even the $160 to $240m seems wild, given that some states may not open theaters at that point (Broadway for example is not going to open by Sept.). While there is a lot of momentum for it to come out and theaters do seem to be opening up a bit, there is still a chance they delay the movie until the Fall or 2021, so need to have some probability for less than $1m: 20%? Putting the vast majority of weight on the $1 to $80m range, as I do think it is going to come out, but I don't see it being open everywhere in the US.

Considerably upping my estimate for less than $1 million. I hadn't previously given enough weight to the possibility of the release being ultimately delayed by one or more months, e.g. if enough cinemas worldwide have not yet opened as suggested in this article [1].  If it is delayed, the article's sources suggest it would likely be until mid-August in the first instance, or otherwise until September. If August, this would almost certainly place the movie in the $1-80 million category by September; if September or later, it would be <$1 million.  I now judge it more likely than not that insufficient cinemas will start opening in the next month for Tenet to keep its original release date, with around a 1 in 5 chance of further delays until September. I've updated my estimates accordingly. [1] https://deadline.com/2020/05/tenet-coronavirus-release-date-change-movie-theaters-1202928823/

My earlier forecast[1] did not give enough weight to the likelihood that the release date is delayed....the following quote[2] really helps put that in perspective:  “ Due to its high price tag (Tenet is estimated to cost $200 million, even without marketing), Deadline says WB needs a minimum of 80% of the world's theaters to be open to justify keeping the film on July 17.” Similar views indicated @ [3].  [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1030993
[2] https://screenrant.com/wonder-woman-1984-release-date-delay-tenet/
[3] https://deadline.com/2020/05/tenet-coronavirus-release-date-change-movie-theaters-1202928823/

"Solid sources hear that Warner Bros needs at least 80% of the world’s theaters to be open, including New York, Los Angeles, and San Francisco (which rep 25% of a pic’s opening weekend), in order to keep Tenet on its original release date" (https://deadline.com/2020/05/tenet-coronavirus-release-date-change-movie-theaters-1202928823/).  Let's guess that there's a 60% chance the premiere gets pushed back. Of that, we'll assume that about half the time its premiere gets pushed after Sept 8 and makes almost no money. For the 40% chance is does premiere on schedule, let's estimate that it makes between 100 and 200 million, with a little bit of a margin on either side. And we'll assign 1% to >240 million just in case there's some sign that it'll have a relatively normal release -- I expect it would have made between 250-350 million in a non-COVID world.

The audience will be adults, free will, boredom all come into play.  The movie cost of $200M had to have been budgeted expecting much more (say $800M during this timefram https://www.reddit.com/r/boxoffice/comments/eu5tgp/realistic_numbers_for_tenet/). Even with 50% seating or whatever ratio to maintain distancing, I think it still gets some high numbers from other showings.

The last part of the question is key:  This question's closing date will not be changed to accommodate any rescheduling of the film's release. It's fairly clear there won't be a cure for COVID-19 by September, and movie theaters are one of the highest risk vectors I can think of for coronavirus transmission. I think there are fairly good odds that few to no movie theaters will be open in 2020.

If there won't be an audience to watch the movie due to closed cinemas or lack of people going to cinemas, I assume they'll reschedule. It does not make sense to release the movie if you don't have the chance of people watching it. The production costs are 205 million, assuming marketing costs not included [1]. It's just not financially viable and I can't imagine how it could be, even if more and more people are starting to go watch movies in cinemas again.  [1] https://www.indiewire.com/2020/01/tenet-budget-205-million-christopher-nolan-plan-1202202123/

People will become restless during extended lockdowns, which will result in a rebound in willingness to both a) risk catching covid in context of controlled outbreaks (similar to current situation in Australia for example) and b) spend money on attending cinema due to restrictions. Overall I expect this to mean a strong box office result slightly below the average of Interstellar and Inception ($240 million).

Two similar Christopher Nolan movies, Interstellar and Inception, grossed $188m and $292m, respectively [1]. Taking the average gives $240m best estimate in the absence of COVID. I revised this down slightly to $210m for the US market given it reputedly has a very long runtime. An Ipsos poll [2] suggests that 27% of 4,429 polled Americans would return to cinemas when they re-open, with 32% saying they would wait for a vaccine. I think this number will probably increase slightly by July if cases fall and cinemas show they have good measures for social distancing, and the movie may benefit from being the first to open and having little competition over the summer. So I estimate they might see 40% of "normal" turnout, giving a best estimate of $84m. I revised my estimate down a bit given I see more scenarios where gross is significantly lower (e.g. lower-than-expected declines in COVID prevalence) than significantly higher. [1] https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0816692/?ref_=nm_knf_i1 and https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1375666/?ref_=nm_knf_i4
[2] https://variety.com/2020/music/news/coronavirus-movies-films-concerts-return-poll-1234592161/

Historic references (to arrive at a non-COVID base rate) are gross numbers for Dunkirk and Inception, both by Nolan, which were $183MM and $279MM, respectively. (Eight week period following same opening weekend in July) I simply averaged the two. From there, I look at a Monte Carlo assuming average of 50-75% of theaters (strikes me as potentially high) are open in the country, operating at 25-50% of capacity. This results in a mean box office gross over the period of $52MM, with a stdev of $11MM, putting 98.8% of all outcomes in the second bucket ($1MM≤x≤$80MM), and 1.2% in the third ($80MM<X<$160MM).  I have increased weight of the third bucket (to 3%), given that it seems likely that the movie will perform better as a first mover, with so many other film openings being delayed to later in summer or fall.
